participants.participant: Dr. Lothar Steinebach, Executive Vice President Finance (Chief Financial Officer)/Purchasing /IT/Law
Kasper Rorsted, Chief Executive Officer, Human Resources/Infrastructure Services

plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome at our fall Analyst and Investor Conference taking place this time here in London. The agenda that we want to propose to you for today is the following. We will start with an overview of our Q3 results that will be done by our CFO, Lothar Steinebach. That will take about 25 minutes and then we will – for the final reason why we are here – start with Kasper Rorsted, our CEO, who will present you then Henkel's strategy, mid-term targets for 2010 and '12.
This is a short introduction from my side, and we pass over now to Lothar Steinebach for the Q3 results of Henkel.

Welcome again, on behalf of the Henkel management team. I'll start with financials for Q3, since I have only 25 minutes I'll skip the disclaimer, and start with the highlights of Q3 2008 key financials.

You've seen that already in our communication, strong sales growth of 12% with even stronger sales growth in the growth regions, plus 24.1%. Organically growth in the total company, 3.5%, adjusted operating profit up 6.3, adjusted earnings per preferred share up 3.5%. That in our view is a solid performance in a challenging environment, as you know obviously know that this challenging environment is not going to go away anytime soon.

Some key facts. Double-digit sales growth in emerging markets, 13.5% organic sales growth that is slightly lower than what we have experienced over the past, but it's still at a very high level. Growth regions increasing share of sales, total Henkel sales to 39%. So we continue on the pace to accelerate the share of sales in the growth regions in our total portfolio.

We're seeing slowing markets in North America, even some decline in Western Europe. We have had yet another successful quarter of strong performance in reducing our net working capital in percent of sales by 110 basis points to 12.8%. We have also generated free cash flow, permitting us to reduce our net debt by €108 million versus prior quarter. And we have instituted additional cost chase measures – initiated additional cost chase measures to take effect in the fourth quarter in order to be able to satisfy expectations that we've seen in the market and also finish with a strong performance full year 2008.

Sales and EBIT performance. Some detail on our divisions, Laundry & Homecare, Personal Care, Adhesive Technologies. First Laundry & Homecare, 3.4% organic growth, which is composed of even stronger growth in terms of price impact, 4.5%, and a negative volume, minus 1.1. Total growth of Henkel, 3.5% organic growth, which again is almost exclusively price driven. And we've seen pricing component in our growth over the quarters from one through two and three now to increase in importance in our total portfolio. So we are now at 3.5% organic sales growth, which is almost entirely or is entirely from pricing activities over the total Company.

With respect to Laundry & Homecare, we have implemented successfully price increases, in major part obviously in the emerging countries and the growth regions, which has permitted us to realize strong growth in terms of pricing impact on our total growth. We've also started price increases in Western Europe and we have announced and initiated price increases in North America. Some parts in Europe have already been implemented and have taken effect, but not all. So therefore, pricing impact, particularly from Western Europe and North America should increase in the fourth quarter, once again, over the third quarter.

And we have continued to have strong organic growth in the emerging markets in our Laundry & Homecare division. Again, double-digit growth in emerging markets, which is a very strong performance even for the strong growth that we see in the markets there.

Personal Care's organic growth 3.4%; of which 0.7 is price and 2.7, volume. So here again, there is less of pressure on the input side on the Personal Care business and therefore we have been able to increase our volume without having the need for particular pricing activities in order to improve our margin. So major part of our growth in Personal Care is from volume growth, market share gains which we have realized, particularly in Western Europe.

In terms of business units, strategic business units which have been performing particularly well in our Personal Care portfolio, the Hair and Body, that being the growth drivers, and we've had continuing strong growth in the emerging markets, which is not a surprise, but perhaps another surprise is our strong growth in North America organic growth, which we have experienced already in the second quarter. You may remember that I've pointed that out after the second quarter and we've continued with our organic growth in North America against the weak market.

Adhesive Technology, 3.6, again, big impact from price, 4.7%, negative impact from volume. We have seen the industrial business weakening in the third quarter already. Building has continued on a robust growth path, which is a major part in Eastern Europe continues to grow strongly. We have again experienced good growth in emerging markets, with weaker industrial sales in North America and Western Europe.

We've also taken some actions to get rid of underperforming parts of our business there, so therefore that accounts for part of the volume decrease, it's not entirely the market. We've deliberately priced some of our products such that we get either higher margins or else get out of this business. So therefore that has contributed to the negative volume growth that we have experienced.

Sales growth by region; again differentiated by foreign exchange adjusted and organic growth. Europe, Africa, Middle East, it's a little bit difficult to interpret because it is obviously composed of Eastern Europe and Western Europe. And I mentioned earlier that Western Europe has been weak and Eastern Europe continues to be strong. So therefore the mix 3.7 is good growth given the portfolio, the stronger part – bigger part still in Western Europe of total sales.

North America, slight organic growth, slightly ahead of last year which means that parts of our business, particularly the industrial sector have been below last year and parts, and I mentioned, particularly cosmetics, have been ahead of last year in terms of organic sales growth.
Another strong quarter for Latin America, our businesses in Latin America, 12.4% organic growth; that is a very strong performance and continues to be one of our highlights.

Asia Pacific, weaker organic growth, we've seen third quarter impacted by some of the weakness already in the industrial sector. You know that some of the steel companies in China have not resumed, for a period of time, production and therefore some of that has had an impact on our businesses as well.

Taking emerging countries, growth regions together, double-digit growth, 13.5%, I mentioned that at the very beginning, in our highlights, 13.5% organic growth. So that's the composition of all the emerging markets in which we're in with a strong performance in Latin America and Eastern Europe.

EBIT growth by business sector, with an impact on the margin, Laundry & Homecare with a negative EBIT growth compared to last year – last year's quarter, minus 90 basis points change but still on a high level, 11.0%. That's still a very satisfactory performance given the challenging environment.

We have experienced, particularly in the first six months, significant raw material cost increases, which we have not yet been able to fully offset. And I mentioned that some of the raw material price increases which have hit us in the first six months will continue to have an impact in the second six months, particularly the third quarter.

It is an improvement of 160 basis points over the second quarter. So therefore that already shows that our pricing actions should have an impact, have improved our situation in terms of margin and we expect that to continue into the fourth quarter, where we see a leveling off of the impact of raw material price increases, while our price increases will take then full effect, particularly in Western Europe, some of those countries in Western Europe and in North America.

Adhesive Technologies was minus 200 basis points compared to last year's Q3. First of all, we've had significant raw material price increases. Here again, we're trailing in terms of offsetting raw material price increases by our own price increases but we're on a very good track.
And I mention that some of the actions that we've taken in order to eliminate low margin businesses have had an impact on volume but have had a positive impact on margin.
Without the impact of the integration costs of 19 million, the downturn would have been only 100 basis points. So there again, we're on a good path forward.

Let us try to explain the difference between the way we've been reporting our central R&D expenses last year versus this year. We had a portion of our R&D as a central R&D unit, reported under corporate. We have reassigned all the units that have been part of the central R&D unit into the business divisions. We've communicated about this extensively. This is just showing the impact on the margin as a result of reassigning resources to the Laundry & Homecare division. We've had a negative of 30 basis points, or put differently, without this action, margin in Laundry & Homecare would have been 11.3%. Under the same scenario, margin in Personal Care would have been 12.7% and Adhesives Technologies 9.2%.

There's obviously no impact on total Group because that's a reassignment from corporate into the business divisions, but obviously it's important to understand the special changes that we've been implementing.

Adjusted earnings, how do we get to adjusted earnings and the 6.3% growth over last year? Reported operating earnings, reported EBIT 191, one-time charges 19 million, normal restructuring 4 million, pretty low level, extraordinary restructuring 177. I'll show in a second what that is composed of.
That therefore results in adjusted EBIT of 391 or 6.3% growth over last year. Margin minus 60 basis points compared to last year.
Global Excellence accounts for 168 million of the 177 and National Starch 9 million.

Income statement, this is providing some more detail on the development of our GP1 margin, gross profit margin. As you can see, as reported we have a decrease of 470 basis points to 41.8. How has that come about? This is providing the detail. We have had an increase in GP1 margin by price volume impact of two percentage points, we've had a negative impact of cost of sales, raw material price increases of 2.4% and others – various others 0.4% positive.

Therefore, without special impacts, which I will explain in a second, we would have had the same margin that we had last year. So we're stable in terms of the operating GP1 margin on a normalized level.

Further, negative impact from the restructuring expenses that we've taken 2.9% and National Starch, which is composed basically of two things. The one is the margin, GP1 margin of National Starch is lower than the Henkel average. So therefore initially National Starch on a GP1 level is dilutive. Plus there's an impact from raw material price increases. Again, the negative impact on the National Starch business.
Now following the realization of synergies, National Starch won't be dilutive on the GP1 level, but initially, and we communicated this, it is dilutive. So that therefore closes the gap to the 41.8%.
Price increases contained in the cost of sales National Starch and Henkel of more than 120 million in this quarter for direct materials and including National Starch.

Restructuring charges by cost line, total of 181, composed of 98 relating to cost of sales, 17 to marketing, selling and distribution expenses, 45 to R&D, and administrative expenses 21. That then adds up to 181, I hope.

Income statement adjusted for restructuring, gross profit to adjusted EBIT. First of all sales, cost of sales, numbers that you know, gross profit 1.670, and we have changes in R&D and administrative expenses, increases by 20% or 28%.

Explanation, we have a higher R&D ratio compared to total Henkel in the National Starch business. There again, there'll be some synergies to be realized and therefore the ratio is going to come down somewhat.

You also know from, I guess from history, from memory, that the R&D ratio in our Adhesive Technology business is above the Henkel average. So the 3.1% that we have inherited with the National Starch business is not unusual. Our Technology business has been above 3% as well. But obviously, it is increasing total expenses for R&D on the Group level and thereby increasing the ratio somewhat initially.

Second, with respect to administrative expenses, there again that's pre-synergies, that's an increase through the acquisition and there are two impacts. First of all, we are taking over an existing business which runs with its own structure and has been running with its own structure, which in turn permits us to realize synergies, because obviously once integrated into our administrative processes, we'll be utilizing much fewer resources than what we do need at the very beginning when taking over the business.
So that's therefore an initial negative impact in terms of administrative expenses on the Group and therefore part of the synergy realization story that we expect for National Starch.

Changes in the financial results. In Q3, we have a negative of 48 million compared to 22 the year before. Here's the explanation. It's not the investment result, it is entirely in net interest. An increase in net interest is entirely due to the fact that we had to finance the National Starch acquisition. Obviously last year we did not have the additional debt that we took on in order to finance the National Starch acquisition.
That again is composed of partly additional debt capital and utilization of cash that we would otherwise have invested and generated returns.

Cash flow from operating activities changed in one through nine of this year versus last year. We have a higher rate of depreciation of non-current assets. That again is a major part or entirely due to depreciation that we've taken in the Global Excellence program. So the difference is entirely due to depreciation that we've taken on as part of the Global Excellence program.

That's our major pride, we've been able to increase or to decrease the ratio of net working capital and cash net working capital to sales. It's a fantastic success story over the past three years, even longer. We started out at 18.1%, we're now at 12.8. Again, another improvement over last year of 110 basis points. That's something which we've been very proud of because it has generated lots of free cash flow that we can utilize to reduce debt and also in order to fund our growth.

Net debt development, that's simple, a little bit more than 108 million, which we have reduced our net debt level at the end of Q3, in major part through free cash flow against which financial – other financial transactions.

Debt structure and maturity, that's perhaps an interesting point these days. In the past five years that I've been CFO of this Company, nobody was ever asking for this but today we are getting questions. What is the maturity profile of our debt, are we secure in terms of our access to funds, what is the situation? We have assured two major bonds, the Hybrid Bond and the Senior Note, 1.3 billion and 1 billion.

Maturity of the Hybrid is 2104, that's a long time to go. Obviously, there's some triggers in – I don't want to argue around it, so therefore there's some likelihood depending on the interest rates obviously that this might be retired in 2014 but be that as it may, the duration of this Hybrid is 2104.

The Senior Note has a duration until 2013 and we have the remaining part of the acquisition financing, which is bridge loan, we've communicated that we've taken basically two tranches of bridge loans. One was 1.6 billion, the other was 1 billion. We have retired the 1 billion already, so that – what is remaining is the 1.6 billion was the duration until 2010.
Now the remainder of our financing is bank and other loans, 1.2 million with further durations in commercial paper and you know that's up to three months.

What is the status of our commercial paper? Interesting because we've been able to access the commercial paper market in the U.S. as well as in Europe without any problems. We're obviously rolling over these amounts every month because there's always one-third that is to be rolled over.

We have not had any issue with getting it done. We're financing still at very attractive rates. I guess you're aware that normally banks in lending to each other use interbank lending rates or else something below that. And today that market is somewhat dry, to put it mildly, but we get financing at interbanking rates minus. So therefore, that's a very attractive financing instrument for us.
We have no immediate need for refinancing. We have therefore – we still have some cash available at the end of September, and therefore we feel in a very secure position in terms of our financing.

Global Excellence and National Starch, we have booked in the third quarter – at the end of third quarter 395 million restructurings of the total volume of 500 million, which we still expect for the full year 2008.

We have confirmed savings of 30 million to be realized already in 2008. We have realized 8 million of that, therefore a little bit more than 20 million remaining for the fourth quarter, which will help us in reaching our targets.
Implementation of the program, albeit difficult is still very well on track, so therefore we're going to get there.

National Starch acquisition, similar picture, although we've booked less, 32 million of restructurings, we still expect to have one time charges of 250 million in 2008. And we have confirmed our expectation to realize 20 million of savings yet in 2008, of which 7 million have already been realized in Q3.

There again, the integration process is well underway, which means that we have established the structure that we wanted to establish in order to go forward with this business as an integrated part of the Henkel businesses, of the UA business of Henkel.

We've also pretty much confirmed and defined what other actions we need to take in order to go through the other items of restructuring and therefore we're very well on track in getting our program executed in the terms that I described.

Updated outlook, what are the trading conditions that we expect for the rest of this year? We've seen slowing markets in North America and Western Europe already. That's going to continue. You've seen how some of the announcements that some of our customers have already made, closed down their facilities for a week or extend Christmas holidays or similar actions.

So therefore, while we do expect, and that's based on statistics that are publicly available, that total car production will be slightly ahead of last year in total. We do expect that fourth quarter will be a weaker quarter in that respect.
We do expect emerging markets with further expansion. We've seen a little bit of slowdown but not much. You've seen the 13.5% which we have experienced in the third quarter.

We do expect consumer spending to be stable. That doesn't mean that the competitive situation is alleviating, it's going to be as tough as it has always been and it remains our job to maintain and increase our market share. Industry output is expected to weaken over the fourth quarter.

We still see some direct material cost increases which have peaked in the third quarter and therefore we would expect stabilization at a high single-digit level. What we expect is that the decrease – the rapid decrease in the oil price obviously will come into the system of raw materials with a time delay between three and six months. That's what we always communicated.

We've seen the peak of the oil price at the end of the second quarter, so therefore we'll see a little bit of relief already in the fourth quarter and some more then in next year. And we expect the dollar to remain strong for the time being, at least for the fourth quarter.
Overall, we would describe the environment to remain challenging certainly for the fourth quarter of this year.
This is the updated outlook. Sales, we confirm our 3 to 5% organic sales growth. One through nine were 4.3%, so we feel pretty confident that we're going to make our 3 to 5% organic sales growth.
One-time charges and restructuring charges to be adjusted in order to arrive at adjusted EBIT, 770 to 780, that's the number that we've communicated.

Consistently adjusted EBIT, Henkel, around 10% based on EBIT OF 1,370 of last year. That should be within expectations of the market. Adjusted EPS, based on €2.19, in the low to single-digit commensurate with the adjusted EBIT increase.

Nevertheless, that therefore requires a strong finish that we need to deliver in the fourth quarter and we have taken all actions that are needed in order for us to be able to deliver a strong finish.

We continue to expect strong organic sales growth in the emerging markets and we'll continue to have an impact from the price increases not only in the emerging markets but also in the mature countries where we have announced and implemented the price increases already.

Characterizing our business performance, we would describe Laundry & Homecare as catching up. We've been trailing some of the strong impact from the raw material price increases in the first six months. We've taken actions, counter actions and we're now getting the benefit.

Personal Care is very well on track. That's a fantastic performance that we've seen on Personal Care in terms of sales growth as well as margin improvement, so therefore, that's a very strong finish that we're going to expect from Personal Care.

Adhesive Technologies remains challenged, not only because of the increase in the input costs, but also because of what we see in our customer industries that relates to some of the announcements that have been made and some other risks that may be materializing over the next months.

Adjusted EBIT growth in Q4, how do we think that we get to our outlook? First of all, we're getting an additional quarter of National Starch, that's obviously clear. We will have an higher impact from our own price increases and I've been alluding to that several times because of the delay that we had in order to get the price increases into the retail.

We do expect 35 million additional savings from Global Excellence in National Starch based on our expectation for the full year and what we have realized already in Q3 and we have defined an additional savings of 25 million from additional cost chase measures. Lots of different actions which we have communicated into the Henkel organization. Everybody is, perhaps not excited, but certainly fiercely determined to deliver on this promise.
And that therefore, concludes my Q3 and outlook. I hand over to Kasper Rorsted.

Thank you very much, Lothar. I will choose to stand. The title is not chosen randomly; With Focus on Core Business to Higher Margins. It is chosen very deliberately because we do believe that if we were to pull out one objective for the next four years, it is improving the profitability of our Company to get into the range of what we believe is realistic.

What I'm presenting to you here today has been discussed and agreed with our Board with our top 200 managers and tomorrow we'll have a video broadcast for 5,000 managers across the world. So there is a common and clear understanding of where we're taking it. It has been today communicated internally.
So, it's a plan that has been driven top down with a bottom up input, but it's a plan where we've details behind it on the different activities and from a timing standpoint.

But let me start, we've defined three key priorities and under each of those there is a number of sub-segments that I'll go through today, they'll be the key drivers for taking us forward and defining our strategic objectives for the next four years and the consequent financial consequences of doing this.

The three objectives are, achieving our full business potential; the second is, increasing our focus on our key customers; and the third is, looking upon and strengthening not only our team but the performance of our team.

In order to take you through the presentation I will go through a starting point, where we see the Company today, go through each of the three strategic priorities which I just described, take you through the bridge between the strategic priorities and the financial targets for 2012 and then summarize. And following that we'll have the Q&A session, both on the fiscal year '08, but also the planning between '08 and '12.

We are coming from a position, and these are our assumptions that we maintain our current structure of the Company with three business Groups, the Toiletries and Cosmetics and Adhesives. That is the assumption upon which we built the strategic priorities.

What we're seeing is, and Lothar has alluded to it today, we're seeing a slowdown in the U.S. and also slowdown/stop in Western Europe. We are seeing the financial crisis, it is affecting the overall economy and we are seeing very high volatility in feedstock and currencies.

Just as an example, I was reading the Financial Times this morning, and I'm certain you did the same, oil price was forecasted to be $200 in 2030. Just as a reminder, three months ago when I was reading the Financial Times, oil prices were forecasted to be $200 in the next year. So there's a certain amount of volatility in our planning and I'll also come back to the assumptions upon which we build our plan.
We still see upsides or potential in our emerging regions, not only through household spending but also strong industry.

We're coming, if you take the five-year view on Henkel, from a period of between 3 and 5% organic growth over the last period of time. During that period of time we've also been capable of increasing our operating margin, our profit margin from 8.8 to, at this stage, 10.2%. So we have made overall progress, not to the level that we believe is realistic with the portfolio we have at hand.

We come from a position which started out with the mature markets where we have a strong position in a number of the mature markets. In Europe and in Germany and North America we have a good foundation. But I strongly believe that the real big asset and the long-term assets in our portfolio is coming out of emerging regions.

What I tried to do here is just giving you two different pictures. There is the category picture from Cosmetics and Detergents, and in the category picture we have approximately 100 plus number one or number two positions in the emerging markets. And you can see emerging markets for Detergents and Cosmetics is defined as the emerging market minus Asia Pacific because we hardly have any presence there. So we have a very, very strong position in Eastern Europe, Middle East Africa and we'll build upon that more than 100 leading positions.

From a country standpoint, because that is a more relevant measure point in our Adhesives business, in our emerging countries we have 35 number one positions, meaning that we are the largest adhesives and surface treatment company in 35 countries in our emerging regions.

We believe that we've taken a number of steps this year, and this year has been a busy year, that will prepare us for next year. We have a good and solid business position. We have a very strong position in our emerging countries; Lothar mentioned that 39% of our overall business is coming from emerging countries. We have initiated Global Excellence very early. I've seen a lot of other Companies also gone in for restructuring and we started out early, which I think will be advantageous for us.

National Starch, which Lothar also mentioned, and we've taken some fairly radical cost cuts, looking upon and addressing the current financial outlook. Our target is also to retain our A rating and looking upon it and taking that very, very serious, and we don't have any need for refinancing between now and 2010. What this slide also explains is that right now, large transactions is not a priority for us, it is down to basic execution and getting the profitability improvements through our P&L.
Now, let me take you through the strategic priorities and articulate how we see some of the very important steps to get to the increase in our profitability level.
I'll go through on the full business potential, four different elements, the portfolio, our brands, innovation and operational excellence, starting out with our portfolio.
What we've done is, and I'll speak in portfolio – in several categories when it comes to regions and when it comes to products.
In our Laundry & Homecare it's clear that we need to improve our profitability in our mass categories, and I'll come back to articulate how later.
So, increased profitability, not necessarily volume in our mass categories and increased volume in our specialty categories where we have much higher profitability.

Within Cosmetics it's keeping the high innovation rate where it is, because that is allowing us to improve the margin improvement that you've seen, so we continue with the focus on our innovation rate through that drive our margins up, and use Schwarzkopf as the overall master brand and build that for the future.

In Adhesives, it's driving growth back into our specialty solutions, these are the high margin businesses, it exploits the scale effect in industrial adhesives around National Starch. The less specialty part is where we need to get the scale effects and utilization out of our manufacturing side and then, through innovation and selective pricing, improve profitability in automotive and consumer business. This could – and the latter also mean decrease in topline through aggressive pricing. You've seen that in the second and third quarter, we'll continue that strategy moving forward.

When it comes to our regional strategy, it's a balance between mature markets and emerging markets. In our mature markets, it's protecting and gaining market share in the markets we're in. Increased cost is when basically mean flat cost structure or declining cost structure in mature markets, and improved profitability mix our portfolio mix, which I just spoke about in order to drive up profitability.

In our emerging markets is where we're going to focus our investments. We will have disproportionally large investments both as it comes to OpEx and CapEx in our emerging regions. Expand selectively, and what we mean by that is that for us it's more important to have a leading position in a country instead of being in many other countries, so we'll continue to expand, but selectively, with a clear target of getting leadership positions in those markets. And along with that, improve our portfolio mix.

I've taken this picture because it is time for the key profitability improvement measures, moving forward. In 2004, we had 26% of our business coming from our emerging business. One to nine is 37%, the third quarter alone is 39% and our target for 2012 is 45%.

What we've done here is I indexed the EBIT margin just to give you an insight into why this will help improve our margin. In 2004 we indexed at 100, right now it's at 157 and that EBIT margin will go to 190 in 2012 and right now we're balancing, finding the balancing act between revenue growth and improvement in margins.
So what we're seeing is we're seeing a consistent improvement in our EBIT in the emerging regions that help to reach the overall EBIT targets that we set as a Company.
So the target is approximately 45% of our business in 2012 will come from the emerging markets, which gets me to brands.

I've taken here and articulated the nine largest brands for our Company, three by business Group, and what they articulate, let me just explain to you, starting with Laundry & Homecare, we have a market that grows between two and 3%, we grew 5.5% and our top three brands grew 8% and they account for 32%. Likewise for Cosmetics, a market of two to 3%, overall growth of 5.8%, top three brands growing 9%.
And for Adhesives, three to four, 6.5 and 14, a total of 34%, meaning that the top three brands from Henkel as a Company accounts for a quarter of the total business.
If you take the top nine brands, they account for approximately 42% of the business, and they all have over-proportional growth compared to the overall growth of the Company.

Our target this year is to have 2x growth of our top brands from now until 2012; they have higher growth rates and higher margin contribution to our business. So what you're seeing is you're seeing an increased focus on products under those brands, innovation and also sales efforts. So they will, along with our emerging regions, be part of the topline growth drivers, but of course, also, our margin drivers.

What we are doing is, and this is articulating our brand strategies, we are working in three different dimensions. We are strengthening the global brands that we have around Schwarzkopf and Loctite. We have a number of very strong local/regional brands and what we're going to do around those, and which we are doing. We're taking a brand like Persil in Germany, which is the same product in France, it's just called Le Chat.

So the only difference here is the name of the box. R&D, packaging, content, manufacturing is exactly the same, so standardizing around everything in the product. The only thing that remains different is the brand and in very few instances, maintaining local strong brands but moving more and more to the right-hand side in order to get the scale effects either out of the brand, subsequent R&D, packaging and manufacturing, all the same just without the brand. That is the key driver for our brand strategy moving forward.

On the innovation side I think you most probably have seen earlier this year the corporate R&D function that we had. We've taken that function and integrated it back into the business Groups in order to shorten time to market and create high levels of customer proximity. That integration is done and is over.

And the reason why this is so important for us is that we are very much aware that innovation is a key driver for being able to pass price increases on to customers. So in order for us to improve our profitability on our products we need to have a very strong innovation capability. That is the driver for having dissolved the corporate R&D function and brought it back into the business groups.

What we've done, as an example, three recent launches, Vernel, Diadermine and Loctite and what you can see is that on this we have improved the GP1 margin by respectively 10.4, 5.6 and 5%. So we have a very clear strategy articulating each of the business groups that we will only launch products which are accretive to the gross margin, so we are foregoing launches in the innovation process if they are dilutive to gross margin.

That is a process that was started to be implemented approximately 12 to 18 months ago and that is, right now, being implemented across the board, meaning every new product that we bring to market will be accretive to gross margin.
We have approximately 30% of our revenue being generated by products that has been introduced over the last three years.

Let me go to operational excellence. On this we have a number of different initiatives. First of all we are purchasing and we have four different categories. We have global sourcing, i.e., using our global footprint to continue to get better conditions from our global suppliers. It's a program that was initiated in 2005 and we're so to speak, in version two or three at this stage. It's building a stronger emerging market capability to source products from the emerging regions.

It's thirdly, getting much closer to our strategic suppliers, having reduced our supplier portfolio dramatically. All we want to do is to increase the innovation capability through our supplier pipeline.

As an example, very recently, the entire management team with Lothar and myself met up with our largest supplier and spent a full day with that supplier. We didn't speak about Ts and Cs, we spoke about innovation; we spoke about strategic alignment, joint manufacturing capabilities, supply chain capabilities, inventory. And what you're seeing is, like we'll speak about with the customers, spending much more time on the strategic element of the suppliers. The Ts and Cs have to be right but at the same time we've got to have more value out of our suppliers than just Ts and Cs.

And then eventually looking into new business models, are there things that we can do differently in purchasing, purchasing with other companies, also. We expect that these purchasing activities will drive savings to the tune of €350 million by 2012.

Our manufacturing footprint and our supply chain, we are in the process of a large overhaul, so to speak. We have already announced 30 projects in this area through our Global Excellence projects and they're looking upon consolidation. The other thing is if you look at development of oil price and raw material prices earlier this year and now, all those who could have hedged would now be in a very bad position because they would pay a high price even though the prices are coming down.
